block.p: FILMMAKERS from Oscar Micheaux to Spike Lee will be represented in the 16th annual Harlem Week Black Film Festival, which opens on 125th Street on Tuesday and runs through Aug. 13.

The program, which includes more than 50 films, starts with a tribute series for Mr. Micheaux and Spencer Williams, pioneer black directors. Mr. Micheaux wrote, directed and produced more than 35 films between 1918 and 1948. Among those in the festival are ''The Exile,'' ''The Darktown Revue'' and ''Underworld,'' all from the 30's.
FILMMAKERS from Oscar Micheaux to Spike Lee will be represented in the 16th annual Harlem Week Black Film Festival, which opens on 125th Street on Tuesday and runs through Aug. 13.

The program, which includes more than 50 films, starts with a tribute series for Mr. Micheaux and Spencer Williams, pioneer black directors. Mr. Micheaux wrote, directed and produced more than 35 films between 1918 and 1948. Among those in the festival are ''The Exile,'' ''The Darktown Revue'' and ''Underworld,'' all from the 30's.

Among more recent films is Spike Lee's ''Joe's Bed-Stuy Barbershop: We Cut Heads,'' which won a Student Academy Award in 1983. ''Dorothy Dandridge: The Diva's Lost Films,'' edited by Gregory Javan Mills, will feature rare clips from ''Lucky Jordan,'' ''Since You Went Away'' and ''Irene,'' among others.
Shown above is a poster from ''Chicago After Dark,'' a 1946 film by Josh Binney that will be shown on Aug. 13 for the first time in 40 years.

''Harlem Week Black Film Festival'' Tuesday through next Sunday, Art Gallery of the Adam Clayton Powell Jr. State Office Building, 163 West 125th Street at Seventh Avenue; $5; students and people over 65, $4; full festival pass, $40; schedule available at (212) 749-5298 or www.harlem.cc.
